name: Contemporary Issues in Engineering
catalog_description: Seminars on engineering topics such as, ethics, life-long education, engineering standards, project management, risk management, change management, entrepreneurship and innovation, sustainable development, effects of engineering applications on health, environment and safety, legal consequences of engineering solutions. A multidisciplinary group work on a selected theme.

Sectioning and multi-view projections. Assembly modelling and assembling parts. Creating explode view and rendering of assembly drawing. Introduction to animation with Solidworks.

TED UNIVERSITY
ME200
Computer Aided Technical Drawings
SYLLABUS/Fall 2025
Ş. Dizeci Sep. 2024

Course Information

Required

and Classrooms

requisite

struction  Turkish

office hours Sehram.dizeci@tedu.edu.tr
Teaching Assistant(s) Ece.aydin@tedu.edu.tr
Student Assistant(s) -
Lecture notes
Textbook
Recommended 1. Brian Griffiths-Engineering Drawing for Manufacture (Manufacturing Engineering
Reading Modular Series), 2002
2. William E. Howard, Joseph C. Musto, Introduction to Solid Modeling using
SolidWorks, McGraw Hill, 2017
Course Web Pages https://lms.tedu.edu.tr/
Description
Principles of engineering drawing. Principles of computer aided technical drawing. Design 3D parts
with solid modeling, dimensioning and tolerancing. Sectioning and multi-view projections.
Assembly modelling and assembling parts. Creating explode view and rendering of assembly
drawing. Introduction to animation with Solidworks.
Learning outcomes
Having completed this course, students will be able to:
1. Explain principles of engineering drawings and computer aided technical drawing,
2. Perform 2D and 3D design of parts with computer software,
3. Prepare engineering drawings according to different reporting systems,
4. Apply assembly and motion study analysis.

Tentative Course Outline
Week Topics Activities
1-2 Realize the importance of the CAD programs for engineering HW1
3-4 Create 2D fully defined sketches by using dimensions and relations
5 Draw principal views manually from given 3D model HW2
6-7 Generate 3D CAD models HW3, MIDTERM
8-9 Read and understand technical drawings HW4,
10-12 Create assemblies and assign mates between parts HW5
13 Animate assemblies
14 FEM Simulations with SolidWorks Final
Course Policy and Some Remarks
General
• Do not use your cellphones during the lectures.
• All cellphones should be silenced and handed over before the exam starts.

• Midterm exam dates will be announced at least a week before the exam date.
Attendance
You are expected to attend all classes. Classes start on time. Show respect for your classmates
by being on time.
Late Assignment Submission
For each day after the announced deadline, 20% of the total earned mark will be deducted. More
than two days of late submissions will not be accepted.
Make Up Exams
Make-ups for midterm exams will NOT be offered generally. If you have a legitimate reason for
missing an exam, then you must arrange to make up the exam BEFORE the scheduled time of the
exam. The only exceptions are illness or emergency. In case of an illness or emergency you need
to supply documentation supporting your claim.
For further information, refer to University Rules and Regulations documents:
https://www.tedu.edu.tr/tr/main/yonetmelikler-ve-yonergeler
Calculator Policy
You may use a scientific calculator during exams. Programming the calculator before or during
the exams is not allowed.
Plagiarism
Any of the following is considered as plagiarism:
• “Turning in someone else’s work as your own
• Copying words or ideas from someone else without giving credit
• Failing to put a quotation in quotation marks
• Supplying incorrect information about the source of a quotation
• Changing words but copying the sentence structure of a source without giving credit
• Copying so many words or ideas from a source that it makes up the majority of
your work, whether you give credit or not” (Ref. : www.plagiarism.org)
Plagiarism is a very serious offense and will be penalized accordingly by the university disciplinary
committee. The best way to avoid accidentally plagiarizing is to work on your own before you ask
for the help of other resources. Collaboration on non-collected homework and in studying is
strongly encouraged; however, the work you hand in must be solely your own. For more
information on TEDU policy on intellectual integrity refer to:
https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf
Cheating
Cheating has a very broad description which can be summarized as “acting dishonestly”. Some of
Ş. Dizeci Sep. 2020

the things that can be considered as cheating are: copying answers during exams, homeworks
and labs, using prohibited material on exams, lying to gain any type of advantage in class,
providing false, modified or forged data in a report, plagiarizing, modifying graded material to be
re-graded, causing harm to colleagues by distributing false information about an exam,
homework or lab. Cheating is a very serious offense and will be penalized accordingly by the
university disciplinary committee. For more information on TEDU policy on intellectual integrity,
refer to: https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf

to:
https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf

name: Materials Science
catalog_description: Materials and properties. Atomic bonding and arrangement. Structural imperfections. Atom movements. Elastic and viscoelastic deformation of materials. Equilibrium diagrams. Metals and their properties. Modification of properties of materials through changes in structure. Advanced materials and their properties.
learning_outcomes:
Learning Outcomes:
Upon succesful completion of this course, a student will be able to
1. look at materials of different sorts as structures on the atomic level, on the microscopic level and on the macroscopic level.
2. understand why atoms, ions and/or molecules assemble into particular crystal structures.
3. understand how certain structures dictate certain properties.
4. select engineering materials  for different applications
5. identify appropriate materials based on required physical and chemical properties

name: Manufacturing Processes
catalog_description: Fundamentals of manufacturing technologies with a special emphasis on manufacturing of metallic parts. Casting, metal forming and metal cutting processes. Manufacturing processes for non-metallic materials and micro-electronics. Economic process design considerations. Material selection for manufacturing. Manufacturing automation.

TED UNIVERSITY
ME221
Manufacturing processes
SYLLABUS/Fall 2025
Ş. Dizeci Sep. 2023

Course Information
Required or Required
Elective  Elective
Date Sep 2025
Semester Fall 2025 Lecture Hours
Mon 11-13, Tue 13-15
and Classrooms
Course Credit
Pre-requisite/ Co-
Hours/ ECTS (2+0+2) 3 / 5
requisite
None
credits
Language of In- English
Level of Course B.Sc.
struction  Turkish
Assoc. Prof. Dr. Şehram Dizeci (Room
Instructor(s) and D306)
office hours sehram.dizeci@tedu.edu.tr
Teaching Assistant(s) aseckin.kaplan@tedu.edu.tr
Student Assistant(s) -
Lecture notes
Textbook Mikell P. Groover-Principles of Modern Manufacturing, Wiley
Recommended
Reading Dieter, Schmidt- Engineering Design, McGraw.Hill
Course Web Pages https://lms.tedu.edu.tr/
Description
Fundamentals of manufacturing technologies with a special emphasis on manufacturing
metallic parts. Casting, metal forming and metal cutting processes. Manufacturing
processes for non-metallic materials and micro-electronics. Economic process design
considerations. Material selection for manufacturing. Manufacturing automation.
Learning outcomes
Having completed this course, students will be able to:
1. develop knowledge in material science, physical properties of materials and metrology,
2. identify manufacturing processes (casting, forming, cutting, welding, etc),
3. be familiar with manufacturing methods for metallic materials and non-metallic materials,
4. assess different manufacturing operations from economical and product design aspects
and be familiar with computer aided manufacturing,
5. acquire knowledge about modern automation and handling systems,
6. be familiar with engineering metrology and quality assurance.

Bloom’s Taxonomy Levels: (C) Comprehension, (a) Application, (A) Analyze, (E) Evaluate
Assignments
• HW’s: 10%. will have homework and reports during the semester
• Quizzes: 10%. will have online quizzes during the semester
• Term project: 10%. must take assigned Coursera course and complete thoroughly.
• Midterm: 30%, tentative date is, MT: 14/11/2020.
• Final exam: 30%, date will be announced by the university.
• Attendance: 10%, more than 4 sessions of absence will get zero.

quizzes

Extended Description
Extended Catalogue Description Metallurgical fundamentals, bonds, dislocations and
deformation mechanisms. Fundamental concepts from theory of plasticity, true strain and
stress, yield criteria and flow rule. Analytical analysis methods, lower bound, upper bound
and slab method. Basic bulk and sheet metal forming processes. Metal forming machinery
classification and selection. Energy and resource efficiency in forming.

TED UNIVERSITY
ME345
Mechanics of Materials
SYLLABUS/Fall 2025
Şehram Dizeci Sep. 2022

Course Information
Required or Required
Date September 2025
Elective Elective
Tue: 16:00-18:00
Semester Fall 2025 Lecture Hours
Fri: 13.00-14.00
and Classrooms
Course Credit
Pre-requisite/ Co-
Hours/ ECTS (3+0+0) 3 / 5 ME241 / None
requisite
credits
Language of In- English
Level of Course B.Sc.
struction  Turkish
Instructor(s) and Asst. Prof. Dr. Şehram Dizeci (Room D306)
office hours Sehram.dizeci@tedu.edu.tr
Teaching Assistant(s) ece.aydin@tedu.edu.tr
Student Assistant(s) -
Mechanics of Materials by R. C. Hibbeler, 9th Edition, SI Version Pearson 2014. ISBN:
Textbook
978-981-06-9436-4
Recommended Mechanics of Materials by F. P. Beer, E. R Johnston, J. T DeWolf, D.F. Mazurek: 7th
Reading Edition (Global Edition), McGraw Hill 2015. ISBN: 978-9814595247.
Course Web Pages
https://lms.tedu.edu.tr/
Description
Beam bending. Transverse shear. Torsion. Combined stress due to bending, torsion, shear, and
axial load. Stress-strain transformation. Strain rosettes. Deflection of beams and shafts. Energy
methods: Virtual work, strain energy.
Learning outcomes
Upon successful completion of this course, a student will:
1. use plane stress transformation to find principal stress states,
2. understand the principle of virtual work,
3. understand small-strain elastic-plastic deformation,
4. understand failure modes for materials,
5. develop an awareness of mechanics to provides base for further study and specialization within
solid mechanics, including continuum mechanics; computational mechanics (e.g., finite-element
methods).
Bloom’s Taxonomy Levels: (C) Comprehension, (a) Application, (A) Analyze, (E) Evaluate

Assignments
• Homework (15%): There will be multiple homework,
• Attendance (5%): missing more than 3 sessions and you get nothing,
• Quizzes (%15): you need to attend Active Learning sessions,
• Midterm (30%): There will be one midterm assignment. Tentative dates: 14.11.2025
• Final (35%): There will be a cumulative final exam.
Course Assessments & Learning Outcomes Matrix
Course Learning
Assessment Methods
Outcomes
Midterm Assignments #1, #2, #3, #4, #5
Final Exam #1, #2, #3, #4, #5
Homeworks #1, #2, #3, #4, #5
Extended Description
This course provides Mechanical Engineering students with an awareness of various responses
exhibited by solid engineering materials when subjected to mechanical loadings; an introduction
to the physical mechanisms associated with design-limiting behavior of engineering materials,
especially stiffness, strength, toughness, and durability; an understanding of basic mechanical
properties of engineering materials, testing procedures used to quantify these properties, and
ways in which these properties characterize material response; quantitative skills to deal with
materials-limiting problems in engineering design; and a basis for materials selection in mechanical
design.
Teaching Methods & Learning Activities

 Discussions/Debates  Video Presentations

 Collaborating  Hands-on Activities

 Predict-Observe-Explain  Web Searching
 Microteaching  Experiments

name: Fluid Mechanics
catalog_description: Fundamental principles of fluid mechanics and their application to engineering problems. Fluid statics. Kinematics of fluid flow. Dynamics of fluids. Differential analysis of fluid flow. Conservation of mass, momentum and energy for fluid flow problems. Flow of viscous fluids, simple laminar flow systems.

name: Pre-thesis Seminar
catalog_description: Determination of thesis subject, problem and research question definition. Preparatory work for thesis such as literature review, hypothesis generation and research on Methodology. Presentation of thesis proposal as a seminar. Attending seminars organized as part of the program.

name: Master’s Thesis I
catalog_description: The first step of master’s thesis performed under the supervision of academic staff.

name: Master’s Thesis II
catalog_description: Master’s thesis performed under the supervision of academic staff. This course must be taken in the semesters where the thesis work is in progress.

name: Thesis Proposal
catalog_description: Emphasis on the importance and novelty of dissertation topic. Thesis proposal is defended in front of a thesis monitoring committee during the semester the course is taken.

name: Ph.D. Dissertation I
catalog_description: Ph.D. dissertation studies performed under supervision of an academic advisor. This course must be taken when dissertation work commences.

name: Contemporary Issues in Engineering
catalog_description: Seminars on engineering topics such as, ethics, life-long education, engineering standards, project management, risk management, change management, entrepreneurship and innovation, sustainable development, effects of engineering applications on health, environment and safety, legal consequences of engineering solutions. A multidisciplinary group work on a selected theme.

name: Computer Aided Technical Drawing
catalog_description: Principles of engineering drawing.Principles of computer aided technical drawing. Design 3D parts with solid modeling, dimensioning and tolerancing. Sectioning and multi-view projections. Assembly modelling and assembling parts. Creating explode view and rendering of assembly drawing. Introduction to animation with Solidworks.

TED UNIVERSITY
ME200
Computer Aided Technical Drawings
SYLLABUS/Fall 2025
Ş. Dizeci Sep. 2024

Course Information

Required

Textbook

Reading Modular Series), 2002
2. William E. Howard, Joseph C. Musto, Introduction to Solid Modeling using
SolidWorks, McGraw Hill, 2017
Course Web Pages https://lms.tedu.edu.tr/
Description
Principles of engineering drawing. Principles of computer aided technical drawing. Design 3D parts
with solid modeling, dimensioning and tolerancing. Sectioning and multi-view projections.
Assembly modelling and assembling parts. Creating explode view and rendering of assembly
drawing. Introduction to animation with Solidworks.
Learning outcomes
Having completed this course, students will be able to:
1. Explain principles of engineering drawings and computer aided technical drawing,
2. Perform 2D and 3D design of parts with computer software,
3. Prepare engineering drawings according to different reporting systems,
4. Apply assembly and motion study analysis.

Tentative Course Outline
Week Topics Activities
1-2 Realize the importance of the CAD programs for engineering HW1
3-4 Create 2D fully defined sketches by using dimensions and relations
5 Draw principal views manually from given 3D model HW2
6-7 Generate 3D CAD models HW3, MIDTERM
8-9 Read and understand technical drawings HW4,
10-12 Create assemblies and assign mates between parts HW5
13 Animate assemblies
14 FEM Simulations with SolidWorks Final
Course Policy and Some Remarks
General
• Do not use your cellphones during the lectures.
• All cellphones should be silenced and handed over before the exam starts.

• Midterm exam dates will be announced at least a week before the exam date.
Attendance
You are expected to attend all classes. Classes start on time. Show respect for your classmates
by being on time.
Late Assignment Submission
For each day after the announced deadline, 20% of the total earned mark will be deducted. More
than two days of late submissions will not be accepted.
Make Up Exams
Make-ups for midterm exams will NOT be offered generally. If you have a legitimate reason for
missing an exam, then you must arrange to make up the exam BEFORE the scheduled time of the
exam. The only exceptions are illness or emergency. In case of an illness or emergency you need
to supply documentation supporting your claim.
For further information, refer to University Rules and Regulations documents:
https://www.tedu.edu.tr/tr/main/yonetmelikler-ve-yonergeler
Calculator Policy
You may use a scientific calculator during exams. Programming the calculator before or during
the exams is not allowed.
Plagiarism
Any of the following is considered as plagiarism:
• “Turning in someone else’s work as your own
• Copying words or ideas from someone else without giving credit
• Failing to put a quotation in quotation marks
• Supplying incorrect information about the source of a quotation
• Changing words but copying the sentence structure of a source without giving credit
• Copying so many words or ideas from a source that it makes up the majority of
your work, whether you give credit or not” (Ref. : www.plagiarism.org)
Plagiarism is a very serious offense and will be penalized accordingly by the university disciplinary
committee. The best way to avoid accidentally plagiarizing is to work on your own before you ask
for the help of other resources. Collaboration on non-collected homework and in studying is
strongly encouraged; however, the work you hand in must be solely your own. For more
information on TEDU policy on intellectual integrity refer to:
https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf
Cheating
Cheating has a very broad description which can be summarized as “acting dishonestly”. Some of
Ş. Dizeci Sep. 2020

the things that can be considered as cheating are: copying answers during exams, homeworks
and labs, using prohibited material on exams, lying to gain any type of advantage in class,
providing false, modified or forged data in a report, plagiarizing, modifying graded material to be
re-graded, causing harm to colleagues by distributing false information about an exam,
homework or lab. Cheating is a very serious offense and will be penalized accordingly by the
university disciplinary committee. For more information on TEDU policy on intellectual integrity,
refer to: https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf

to:

name: Materials Science
catalog_description: Materials and properties. Atomic bonding and arrangement. Structural imperfections. Atom movements. Elastic and viscoelastic deformation of materials. Equilibrium diagrams. Metals and their properties. Modification of properties of materials through changes in structure. Advanced materials and their properties.
learning_outcomes:
Learning Outcomes:
Upon succesful completion of this course, a student will be able to
1. look at materials of different sorts as structures on the atomic level, on the microscopic level and on the macroscopic level.
2. understand why atoms, ions and/or molecules assemble into particular crystal structures.
3. understand how certain structures dictate certain properties.
4. select engineering materials  for different applications
5. identify appropriate materials based on required physical and chemical properties

TED UNIVERSITY
ME221
Manufacturing processes
SYLLABUS/Fall 2025
Ş. Dizeci Sep. 2023

Course Information
Required or Required
Elective  Elective
Date Sep 2025
Semester Fall 2025 Lecture Hours
Mon 11-13, Tue 13-15
and Classrooms
Course Credit
Pre-requisite/ Co-
Hours/ ECTS (2+0+2) 3 / 5
requisite
None
credits
Language of In- English
Level of Course B.Sc.
struction  Turkish
Assoc. Prof. Dr. Şehram Dizeci (Room
Instructor(s) and D306)
office hours sehram.dizeci@tedu.edu.tr
Teaching Assistant(s) aseckin.kaplan@tedu.edu.tr
Student Assistant(s) -
Lecture notes
Textbook Mikell P. Groover-Principles of Modern Manufacturing, Wiley
Recommended
Reading Dieter, Schmidt- Engineering Design, McGraw.Hill
Course Web Pages https://lms.tedu.edu.tr/
Description
Fundamentals of manufacturing technologies with a special emphasis on manufacturing
metallic parts. Casting, metal forming and metal cutting processes. Manufacturing
processes for non-metallic materials and micro-electronics. Economic process design
considerations. Material selection for manufacturing. Manufacturing automation.
Learning outcomes
Having completed this course, students will be able to:
1. develop knowledge in material science, physical properties of materials and metrology,
2. identify manufacturing processes (casting, forming, cutting, welding, etc),
3. be familiar with manufacturing methods for metallic materials and non-metallic materials,
4. assess different manufacturing operations from economical and product design aspects
and be familiar with computer aided manufacturing,
5. acquire knowledge about modern automation and handling systems,
6. be familiar with engineering metrology and quality assurance.

Bloom’s Taxonomy Levels: (C) Comprehension, (a) Application, (A) Analyze, (E) Evaluate
Assignments
• HW’s: 10%. will have homework and reports during the semester
• Quizzes: 10%. will have online quizzes during the semester
• Term project: 10%. must take assigned Coursera course and complete thoroughly.
• Midterm: 30%, tentative date is, MT: 14/11/2020.
• Final exam: 30%, date will be announced by the university.
• Attendance: 10%, more than 4 sessions of absence will get zero.

Assessment Methods

quizzes

Extended Description
Extended Catalogue Description Metallurgical fundamentals, bonds, dislocations and
deformation mechanisms. Fundamental concepts from theory of plasticity, true strain and
stress, yield criteria and flow rule. Analytical analysis methods, lower bound, upper bound
and slab method. Basic bulk and sheet metal forming processes. Metal forming machinery
classification and selection. Energy and resource efficiency in forming.

syllabus_pdf_text:
TED UNIVERSITY
ME345
Mechanics of Materials
SYLLABUS/Fall 2025
Şehram Dizeci Sep. 2022

Course Information
Required or Required
Date September 2025
Elective Elective
Tue: 16:00-18:00
Semester Fall 2025 Lecture Hours
Fri: 13.00-14.00
and Classrooms
Course Credit
Pre-requisite/ Co-
Hours/ ECTS (3+0+0) 3 / 5 ME241 / None
requisite
credits
Language of In- English
Level of Course B.Sc.
struction  Turkish
Instructor(s) and Asst. Prof. Dr. Şehram Dizeci (Room D306)
office hours Sehram.dizeci@tedu.edu.tr
Teaching Assistant(s) ece.aydin@tedu.edu.tr
Student Assistant(s) -
Mechanics of Materials by R. C. Hibbeler, 9th Edition, SI Version Pearson 2014. ISBN:
Textbook
978-981-06-9436-4
Recommended Mechanics of Materials by F. P. Beer, E. R Johnston, J. T DeWolf, D.F. Mazurek: 7th
Reading Edition (Global Edition), McGraw Hill 2015. ISBN: 978-9814595247.
Course Web Pages
https://lms.tedu.edu.tr/
Description
Beam bending. Transverse shear. Torsion. Combined stress due to bending, torsion, shear, and
axial load. Stress-strain transformation. Strain rosettes. Deflection of beams and shafts. Energy
methods: Virtual work, strain energy.
Learning outcomes
Upon successful completion of this course, a student will:
1. use plane stress transformation to find principal stress states,
2. understand the principle of virtual work,
3. understand small-strain elastic-plastic deformation,
4. understand failure modes for materials,
5. develop an awareness of mechanics to provides base for further study and specialization within
solid mechanics, including continuum mechanics; computational mechanics (e.g., finite-element
methods).
Bloom’s Taxonomy Levels: (C) Comprehension, (a) Application, (A) Analyze, (E) Evaluate

Assignments
• Homework (15%): There will be multiple homework,
• Attendance (5%): missing more than 3 sessions and you get nothing,
• Quizzes (%15): you need to attend Active Learning sessions,
• Midterm (30%): There will be one midterm assignment. Tentative dates: 14.11.2025
• Final (35%): There will be a cumulative final exam.
Course Assessments & Learning Outcomes Matrix
Course Learning
Assessment Methods
Outcomes
Midterm Assignments #1, #2, #3, #4, #5
Final Exam #1, #2, #3, #4, #5
Homeworks #1, #2, #3, #4, #5
Extended Description
This course provides Mechanical Engineering students with an awareness of various responses
exhibited by solid engineering materials when subjected to mechanical loadings; an introduction
to the physical mechanisms associated with design-limiting behavior of engineering materials,
especially stiffness, strength, toughness, and durability; an understanding of basic mechanical
properties of engineering materials, testing procedures used to quantify these properties, and
ways in which these properties characterize material response; quantitative skills to deal with
materials-limiting problems in engineering design; and a basis for materials selection in mechanical
design.

Course Policy and Some Remarks
General
• Note that all assignments will be online, and all efforts are individual.
• There will be two midterm assignments. Midterm weeks are given in the tentative
schedule but may change.
• Date for the final exam will be announced at the end of the semester. The final exam will
cover all topics.
• Cell phones should be turned off and kept out of sight during the classes. You are not
also allowed to use your computers/ tablets etc. in the classroom.
• If you are late for more than 10 minutes, please do not enter the class.
• You are not allowed to use cell phones during exams.
Attendance
You are expected to attend all classes. Classes start on time. Show respect for your classmates
by being on time.
Late Assignment Submission
For each day after the announced deadline, 20% of the total earned mark will be deducted. More
than two days of late submissions will not be accepted.
Make Up Exams
Make-ups for midterm exams will NOT be offered generally. If you have a legitimate reason for
missing an exam, then you must arrange to make up the exam BEFORE the scheduled time of the
exam. The only exceptions are illness or emergency. In case of an illness or emergency you need
to supply documentation supporting your claim.
For further information, refer to University Rules and Regulations documents:
https://www.tedu.edu.tr/tr/main/yonetmelikler-ve-yonergeler
Calculator Policy
You may use a scientific calculator during exams. Programming the calculator before or during the
exams is not allowed.
Plagiarism
Any of the following is considered as plagiarism:
• “Turning in someone else’s work as your own
• Copying words or ideas from someone else without giving credit
• Failing to put a quotation in quotation marks
• Supplying incorrect information about the source of a quotation
• Changing words but copying the sentence structure of a source without giving credit
Şehram Dizeci Sep. 2022

• Copying so many words or ideas from a source that it makes up the majority of your
work, whether you give credit or not” (Ref. : www.plagiarism.org)
Plagiarism is a very serious offense and will be penalized accordingly by the university disciplinary
committee. The best way to avoid accidentally plagiarizing is to work on your own before you ask
for the help of other resources. Collaboration on non-collected homework and in studying is
strongly encouraged; however, the work you hand in must be solely your own. For more
information on TEDU policy on intellectual integrity refer to:
https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf
Cheating
Cheating has a very broad description which can be summarized as “acting dishonestly”. Some of
the things that can be considered as cheating are: copying answers during exams, homeworks and
labs, using prohibited material on exams, lying to gain any type of advantage in class, providing
false, modified or forged data in a report, plagiarizing, modifying graded material to be re-graded,
causing harm to colleagues by distributing false information about an exam, homework or lab.
Cheating is a very serious offense and will be penalized accordingly by the university disciplinary
committee. For more information on TEDU policy on intellectual integrity, refer to:
https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf
Disability Support
If you have a condition which may interfere with your ability to successfully attend or complete this
module, please contact Dr. Onur Özmen (onur.ozmen@tedu.edu.tr). For more information refer
to:
https://ds.tedu.edu.tr/sites/default/files/content_files/tedu_ogrenci-el-kitabi-2016.pdf

name: Fluid Mechanics
catalog_description: Fundamental principles of fluid mechanics and their application to engineering problems. Fluid statics. Kinematics of fluid flow. Dynamics of fluids. Differential analysis of fluid flow. Conservation of mass, momentum and energy for fluid flow problems. Flow of viscous fluids, simple laminar flow systems.

name: Applied Thermal Systems
catalog_description: Engineering design and thermal systems. Pipeline systems, pipe networks. Pumps, pump systems and power. Mathematical modeling, analysis and simulation of thermal systems. Optimization of thermal systems. Heat exchangers. Application of thermodynamics principles on thermal energy cycles.

name: Propulsion Systems
catalog_description: Introduction to propulsion systems. Aerothermodynamics of ideal air breathing engines. Non-ideal cycle analysis. Performance of propulsion system components. Matching of compressors and turbines.

name: Pre-thesis Seminar
catalog_description: Determination of thesis subject, problem and research question definition. Preparatory work for thesis such as literature review, hypothesis generation and research on Methodology. Presentation of thesis proposal as a seminar. Attending seminars organized as part of the program.

name: Master’s Thesis I
catalog_description: The first step of master’s thesis performed under the supervision of academic staff.

name: Master’s Thesis II
catalog_description: Master’s thesis performed under the supervision of academic staff. This course must be taken in the semesters where the thesis work is in progress.

name: Thesis Proposal
catalog_description: Emphasis on the importance and novelty of dissertation topic. Thesis proposal is defended in front of a thesis monitoring committee during the semester the course is taken.

name: Ph.D. Dissertation I
catalog_description: Ph.D. dissertation studies performed under supervision of an academic advisor. This course must be taken when dissertation work commences.
